head.title: Psychiatric Guide Stirs Up Debate on Disorders

hedline.hl1: Psychiatric Guide Stirs Up Debate on Disorders

abstract.p: Prof Stephan F Taylor letter disputes September 28 Week in Review article on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders of American Psychiatric Assn that adds 'road rage' to its list of mental disorders (S)

block.p: Your Sept. 28 Week in Review article ''You're Not Bad. You're Sick. It's in the Book'' impugns the entire Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders for doing what it is supposed to do: considering, then sometimes rejecting, potential disorders, like the onetime ''self-defeating personality disorder.''

Your Sept. 28 Week in Review article ''You're Not Bad. You're Sick. It's in the Book'' impugns the entire Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders for doing what it is supposed to do: considering, then sometimes rejecting, potential disorders, like the onetime ''self-defeating personality disorder.''
You also fail to note that the manual has been instrumental in standardizing the diagnosis of severe mental disorders like schizophrenia and bipolar affective disorder.

To juxtapose quotations from those who have made a career challenging the existence of any type of mental illness, like the psychiatrist Thomas S. Szasz, with those from a psychologist who proposes a marginal diagnostic category, like ''road rage,'' is unfair to the field of psychiatry.
STEPHAN F. TAYLOR, M.D. Ann Arbor, Mich., Sept. 29, 1997
The writer is an assistant professor of psychiatry, U. of Michigan.
